In short, is the game good?Yes, it's very good.Is it worth my time and money?Yes it is. Although, if you're having doubts about paying full price, I'd strongly suggest to wait for a -50% sale.Is this game for anyone?Yes. The game can be enjoyed by both kids and adults.Linear, open-world or something else?The game uses hub worlds which house connected, individual levels. Very reminiscent of late 90s platformer games. There's a lot of stuff to do in each hub world and the connected levels. Expect around 10-13 hours of playtime to reach the ending and around 20-24 hours to 100% the game.Gameplay mechanics, gimmicks?Pretty varied but all challenges and puzzle are based around LEGO. Each minifig has a specific ability that you'll have to use in order to progress throughout the level. There are some fun minigames sprinkled around the levels, in just enough quantity to keep the player interested.Graphical aesthetics, set pieces and world design?The game looks pleasant to the eye. Level design is varied, rich with little details. Graphical fidelity could be slightly better but it does its job.Audio design and soundtrack?Sound effects are decent. Character voices sounds alright in most cases (with the exception of a few lines of dialogue that sound rather silly). Soundtrack is interesting and uses tracks from the movie. Oddly enough, Batman's "no parents" song from the movie seems to be replaced with a generic drumstep wub-a-thon, for some strange reason (licensing issues maybe?).Plot, story?You play as over-night-chosen-one Emmet (and friends) trying to stop President Business from ruling the world. The game closely follows the story of the movie, although it expands the first two acts of the movie and shortens the 3rd act into just a few levels. This actually works in favour of the game, as you're able to explore more of the areas that were hastily rushed through in the movie. In theory, you could just play the game without watching the movie as the story is explained pretty well in the game. Still, I'd personally recommend watching the movie first.How does the game run?Runs without any issues on my 5 year old PC (Dual-Core 2.66GHz, GeForce 9600GT, 2GB RAM) on 1920x1080 resolution with SSAO and V-Sync turned off. No jittering, no sudden framerate drops. Loading times are usually pretty short. Expect way better perfomance on newer machines than mine.Any details, character, motif, etc. you particularly liked?Yes, the "Bonus Room" is a very cool touch.Anything you didn't like?The game suffers from some really weird collision and clipping bugs. Didn't break the game for me but it was annoying at times, forcing me to restart a level at some point. Also, the minifig selection screen is a mess and doesn't explain which minifig has which ability.Final score?I give The LEGO Movie Videogame a double-decker couch out of 5.

												As a huge fan of the movie and Lego games in general, I got to say this entry into the Lego series by Traveller's Tales is one of the weaker ones. The game's campaign follows the movie closely and each level is based off a key scene from the movie, like Lego Lord of the Rings or Lego Star Wars. In those levels is a fun mix of puzzle solving and platforming using different characters with unique abilities. It's essentially what we've come to expect from all the Lego games up to this point. What makes this one different is that it's actually tying in with a new movie, not just based upon an old franchise. Fortunately, it's tying in with a movie about Legos, a perfect fit. But the syndrome of movie tie-in games rears it's ugly head into The Lego Movie Videogame. It feels more rushed than previous Lego games, like the designers are stretching out scenes in the movie to go on for a 20-30 minute level. It feels like they're padding the game out to be much longer than it should be, and that creates boredom. This reminds me of the Lego games on the Nintendo DS, where the levels are padded out with extremely repetitive puzzles and and button-mashy combat sequences. It's a shame too because I was really looking forward to this game. In terms of everything else, the music and graphics are fantastic and fit the style of the movie perfectly. This is one pretty looking game and is the first of the TT Lego games to be entirely made of Legos, so that's nice. Unfortunately, the core gameplay feels scaled back and TT just gave us the bare minimum, even the open world part of game is contained of small chunks instead of one big world. Really, the game is not bad, I would recommend it if you like the previous Lego games or really enjoyed the movie, it just isn't solid as previous Lego games.UPDATE 12/2/14 - I actually have grown a soft spot for the game so far. I still find Lego City Undercover and Lego Marvel better, but I love the source material so much that, it's hard for me to look at it as the weakest (Lego Indy 2 and Star Wars 3 are much worse), it gets better, trust me.

												Ahh lego, who doesn't have a soft spot for it.If you are new to the series don't let the appearance fool you. While the gameplay is simple in nature it's still very enjoyable for all age groups. Great blend of action and puzzles. Keeping to the tried and tested formula you swap between 2 or more characters (if playing solo). Each character will receive different costumes throughout the story, every costume changes the abilities you can use. Puzzles usually require use of all characters combining abilities to complete the task. Controls are simple and effective, though as with all lego games I would definitely recommend playing with a gamepad (or two).Levels are a little shorter then some of the previous titles, but they do manage to fit a lot of action into each 'scene'. Upon completion you will unlock each of these for freeplay mode (open world). Length of the game gets extended quite a bit because as you progress through the game unlocking more characters, you can use these and return to past levels finding new areas and secrets you couldn't access earlier. Each level is a scene reenacted from the movie while cutscenes are copied directly from the movie itself, though they blend in well with the gameplay.Graphically speaking it looks the part and performance is great overall. The artstyle helps a lot with the humour too which is classic tongue-in-cheek lego. Both adults and children should find it amusing on different levels. Game supports a range of video settings covering some higher end setups, eg, basic AA, 1440p+, 120hz+, DoF toggle etc.  (small note: at the time of writing you need to load into the game itself to change graphic options). No fps caps in place here either folks.Voicework is top notch, all the official voice actors are used and I'm almost certain they managed to get some new lines written too.Does make me sad each time a new lego game is released and it doesn't have online co-op support though. That would be the only small downside. Having played most of them now I can honestly say the last several have been brilliant. LOTR, Marvel and now The Lego Movie Videogame are all well worth picking up, particually if you have a children or friend nearby for some couch co-op. 												Well, even a mediocre Lego game is still above average overall. This one's short. It's got some bugs, but most Lego games do.  Honestly? This game is OK. It follows the movie fairly well, but there are points of divergence. And more than just "makes for a better video game". There are parts that honestly felt like it was an earlier draft of the movie. Which wouldn't surprise me. The game was released the same day the movie hit theaters. That strikes me as a bad idea. You haven't given the movie time to build interest in the game, and the parallel development means that if a change is made for the movie, the game lags behind. This was most noticeable with the cut scenes. They were taken from the movie, but the music is wrong - when it exists at all. Music is added fairly late in the film, and it's entirely possible that the scenes were sent to the game before the music was complete. The music that does exist smacks of "temp tracks". It's just not good, doesn't fit. One scene in particular, taken from the movie, references a specific song.. that's not in the game. Which makes that cut-scene particularly awkward. It has an interesting mechanic in the swapping of pants. You can unlock pants that give you an effect in game. There's only a couple effects that actually make any real difference. And it's more "good idea, bad execution" than anything else. The fact that some of the pants are only available via codes found with the Lego sets for the movie troubles me. Not that the codes are hard to find. I'm sure they were online the day the sets were released, if not sooner. I don't really mind it for something like the alternate character model that the DVD/Blu-Ray comes with a code for, since that's purely cosmetic (though it does give access to a character and thus its abilities sooner). The pants, on the other hand, do have an effect on the game. Again, only one has any major impact, and there's a similar - but not exact - pair in the game you can unlock. Maybe I'm just being a curmudgeon here, I have nothing really against cross promotion in general. As long as it's cosmetic. Overall? Well, the game was on sale, so it's not like I paid anywhere near full price for it. And I certainly got my 'money's worth' out of it. But, on sale is really the only time I would recommend this particular game. Especially given the quality of others in the series, such as Lego Star Wars III and Lego Marvel Superheroes.  Still, if you are looking for more Lego games to feed your addiction, this one can fill the gap nicely.

												By now you should know that if you've ever played a Lego game before that this new one brings nothing new to the table. It focuses on the movie, which is great by the way, and it's split up in 15 missions. There's no true open world this time; there are hubs that can be freely explored with many of the characters, but they're not connected to each other. It isn't all that bad, but I can see why people don't like it this way. In fact, all the hubs could've been connected with a bit of creativity. Just sayin'.The world is built entirely from Lego blocks which looks really cool. It fits the style of the movie perfectly. The graphics are, again, the same as all the other Lego games; colorful and sharp. The game in general performs well, but there were a few times where the framerate dropped for a few seconds.A big part of the sounds and music were also taken from the movie, including the catchy 'Everything is awesome' song.As far as gameplay is concerned, there are a few new tricks. Building stuff with blueprints has potential, but isn't really all that fun. It needs more polish and people should be able to build stuff from scratch, instead of selecting the correct blocks. The master builder move looks great in motion and even though you don't really do anything it's still nice to do and watch.About the missions. Each missions lasts about 15-45 minutes, and it can take much longer than that if you want to collect everything. Collecting everything will take you tens of hours. Finishing the game by just completing the missions will take you about 4-5 hours max. That's pretty short for a Lego game. I'm not the kind to collect and complete all things, but even I thought it was short in comparison to the other games. To be honest, I don't really mind. Every Lego game has the same gameplay and it's quickly wearing thin. Give us something completely new, or add enough new stuff to make it special again. Special and fun, like Lego is supposed to be. In the meantime, this will do. Just don't play it before watching the movie first.[Rating: 72/100]

												If you are a fan of LEGO games, then you are probably going to love this. With a plot loosely based around The Matrix, it features some fantastic sequences, like a high-speed pursuit on a futuristic bike. As Wyldstyle (the female Trinity-esque protagonist) jumps from one vehicle to another while being pursued by the bad guys, it uses LEGO's two character co-op format brilliantly. Matrix 2, eat your hat! Early on though, a lot of the 'action' does involve building and demolition in the construction world. It's a clear nod to the real-world LEGO and you even have to seek out the instructions for the builds. These are identical to the type of instruction leaflets packed with real boxes of LEGO, on of many nice little touches to the game. I haven't watched the movie yet, but it's likely it pretty much recreates most of the scenes from the movie, as previous LEGO movie-tie-ins have. This time of course, with it being LEGO's very own product and movie, they have free reign to go nuts, throwing everything at you like a bucketload of trademarked plastic bricks. It also continues the trend of featuring humorous dialogue and sight gags. It's probably the funniest of all the LEGO games, and quite possibly the best. You rush through plenty of different themed LEGO worlds in the multiverse, donning some nifty apparel, which changes from location to location. There are as usual, plenty of characters to unlock, or purchase in the game. It doesn't really scream originality, with the usual tasks of collecting many, many hidden items  in an attempt to add replayability. It does pretty much what previous LEGO games have done before, but it does this very well, and is nicely graphically polished. Those who avoid LEGO games won't find much here to change their opinion. But fans will simply enjoy the ride. And the annoyingly catchy "Everything is Awesome" song will be rolling around your head for days after. 9/10

												BitzComms Reviews: The Lego Movie Video Game(This review covers the PC - Your experience may differ from platform to platform)I have to be honest with you - The Lego Movie came to me by complete surprise. For all the time I spend on YouTube, no word was spoken of the movie (at least that I saw) until I first saw the trailer for it on TV... But then I was surprised even more when a video game was announced for it - It wasn't even a full year after Lego Marvel Super Heroes came out, and Traveller's Tales came out with a new game already?It was more surprising that the game was coming to all major platforms, INCLUDING next gen platforms like the PS4, Xbox One, Wii U, in addition to the PC, Xbox 360 and PS3... Yikes.The short development period between this and Marvel seemed like a sign that this game was going to blow HARD... But then I played it, and it is probably my favorite Traveller's Tales Lego game of all time.STORY:The game follows the story of the movie down pat... Which might turn off those who haven't seen it yet. I suggest you see the movie before you play the game, but even if you don't, the game doesn't feature EVERY scene from the movie... Some of the scenes that are in the game have parts that were cut from the movie, most likely to keep from spoiling the movie for those who haven't seen it. I won't explain the story itself, because we have a movie for that, and I wouldn't want to spoil anything.PRESENTATION:The Lego games that have been developed by Traveller's Tales over the years have had a reputation of exceptional presentation, and this one is no different. The game is fully voiced, and either they got the celebrity voices from the movie to do the game, or they just got really, really good sound-alikes. If it's the latter, I wouldn't be able to tell the difference because the acting in this game is so damn good. As I said before, the story is presented through scenes from the movie, and while that may sound kind of cheap, you have to keep in mind the short period between the release of this and Marvel. Plus, the scenes look so good already that you won't mind at all. It kind of harkens back to the days of movie tie-ins on the Playstation, which generally used scenes from the movie for the cutscenes of the game. Anyone remember Toy Story 2: Buzz Lightyear to the Rescue? (also developed by Traveller's Tales) The game also makes use of a new animation style - The characters actually move like actual lego... No more bendy, stretchy lego limbs. This is probably done to stay true to the stop-motion style of the movie.GRAPHICS:The game looks amazing, as everything is made of Lego this time around. The game also runs really well on low-end machines like mine, and that's always a plus.SOUND:Everything is Awesome!GAMEPLAY:Here's where things get pretty iffy - The game itself is a mixed bag. While this is my favorite TT Lego title so far, I can't deny this game has some serious problems. Let's first talk about the character selection - There are over NINETY characters... NINETY CHARACTERS. Don't get too excited though, as most of the characters are either clones of existing characters, or very minor characters that no one cares about. Most of the characters are different suits for Emmet. Wild Style or Unikitty. There are some good ones in this game, such as Lord Business, Metalbeard, Batman, Super Man, The Green Lantern, Wonder Woman and even the Green Ninja from Lego Ninjago.Emmet himself is a pretty boring character as well. For the majority of the game, all he can really do is use instruction builds. He can't use master builds, and he doesn't have any interesting attacks or gimmicks. Most of the time, you'll be playing as Wild Style, Batman and Unikitty, switching to Emmet only when you need to use an instruction build. Eventually Emmet gets the ability to use Master Builds, but that's very late in the game.Next, let's talk about the gameplay. The game follows the same basic formula as any other TT Lego title before it - Go through the levels, collecting studs and accomplishing objectives with preset characters, then go back and play those levels as any character to find hidden unlockables - Only this time it's mixed with free-roaming hub worlds, and my GOD these are underwhelming. Compared to Lego City: Undercover and especially Lego Marvel Super Heroes, these free-roaming segments seem to be just an after-thought. They are very small and contained. Not very much fun.Next, let's talk about the levels for a minute. The levels are probably the best part of the game, with only a few stinkers here and there. The only problem is that many of them are very long, and when there's a bad level, there's a REALLY bad level. Each level is quite interesting, with its own gimmick and setpieces. There's an entire level that takes place on an under-constuction submarine that's careening down an ablaze Cloud Cuckoo Land. Many of the level designs are very inspired and smart, but they are quite long, and if you don't have a lot of time for one session, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. There are checkpoints placed around the levels that allow you to save your progress, but some of them are placed in areas where you really wouldn't notice them... oops.THE VERDICT:As a whole, however, The Lego Movie Video Game is quite solid, considering the short development period. There's a lot of content in here, and most of the levels are fun, if not a bit too long. I'm giving this game a 7.0 out of 10.

Posted: March 4
												While not inherently a bad game per se, this is easily the worst of all the latest iteration of LEGO games (i.e. those with voice acting and an open-world-ish structure).  It's still a LEGO game, so it's still fun, but it suffers from major issues that other games in the series don't have (or don't have in such proportions):- The Hub worlds are pointless and confusing.  There's nothing to do save for a few easy puzzles that allow you to collect the prized red bricks.  Otherwise, there are no side-quest, no races, nothing else to do.  The highest challenge is to try to navigate their preposterous structure, for which the camera and aribtrary invisible walls will be a constant problem.  You'll hate Cloud Cuckooland the worse.- The two-hour movie is painfully padded to fit a 10-15 hour game (depending if you're hunting for achievements or not).  In consequence, if you haven't watched you'll soon forget what the story is about.  Terribly, a major plot twist of the film is absent from this game for no explanation, which renders the entire thing into a generic adventure.  Again, those who haven't watched the film will be at a loss.- Free Play is broken.  Even though the entire point of Free Play is to be able to breeze through a scene with any character of your choosing in order to get all the hidden items, many times you're forced to play entire parts the exact way you'd do it in normal play or the stage will lock and won't advance.- This is probably the buggiest of the LEGO games, and that's saying a lot, because they're all incredibly buggy.  Expect being forced to restart a stage or maybe even the entire game if you want to 100% it.  Speaking of which, if you're going for all achievements, expect to waste a lot of time doing stuff that's not fun, just repetitive.- The game is confusing in several areas besides camera movement.  Character unlocks happen without rhyme or reason.  Even with the proper red bricks unlocked you'll still have trouble trying to find all the secrets, since some of the arrows don't actually point at what you're supposed to do, or even at where the secret will appear.  The game doesn't bother to explain the point of the unlockable pants or how some abilities are used (and what characters have them).  There's a lot of trial and error.- This might be a nitpick, but the game's main theme music is completely uninspired.  While generally LEGO games beat you with a musical theme until you get sick of it, this one gets you sick of it almost as soon as it starts.Still, there are some good things.  Gameplay is as good as ever, with a lot of interesting new abilities.  Dialogue-wise, this is one of the funniest games in the series (and it retains the same voice cast from the film).  Instruction building is a neat way to get some money early in the game (though it quickly becomes a nuisance as soon as you got any multiplier red brick).So, despite all its flaws, I still recommend the game... provided it's at a hefty discount.  Don't even think to pay the current (as of this writing, $19.99) price.

												My favourite games from this series will always be the Original Trilogy episodes of the Star Wars games. There was something simple and charming about those games that will always appeal to me more than the quagmire that a few of the later games sunk into, in my opinion. I felt later games disappeared into a hole of fiddly complexity regarding character abilities and level design that sucked the fun out of playing.  In saying that, The Lego Movie: The Game rises above a lot of the others I've played, giving you multiple open-world hubs to play around in, as well as some entertaining levels that expand competently upon the movie's premise and retain the sense of fun and variety that Lego embodies as a product. The voice acting is very good considering that the actors are mimicking the original stars, and it's rare that you feel like you're not ACTUALLY listening to the movie's actors. My only sizable criticism comes from that point when you realise that there isn't actually much gameplay in these games, and it mostly relies on your compulsive desire to keep collecting studs to keep you entertained. At that point I found myself wondering whether I was either playing a cheap cash-in, or whether I was playing a decent Lego game and it was just that the series is designed in such a way that, by exploited our completionist desires, they can squeeze the most amount of fun out of the least amount of effort. If it's the former, it's hard to tell, and if it's the latter, I feel like I have to applaud the developers for their ingenuity. Either way, I had fun while I was doing it, alhough I probably won't feel any reason to come back to this particular game after I've finished, as opposed to the Original Trilogy games, as my attachment to the Lego Movie was not great enough to make that a specific draw for me. One last criticism is that I found the music to be annoying as ♥♥♥♥. I'm not a fan of the ethereal electronic soundtrack, and in the film the Everything is Awesome song is supposed to be a satirical take on bland, emotionless, corporate-built pop that is intended to be an ear-worm in the most annoying possible way. So when the developers decided to slap it all over the place in this game and have it haunt the dreams of everyone who plays it, they either missed the point of the film entirely in that regard, or they're ♥♥♥♥ing with us.7/10

Posted: July 20, 2014
												This is the shortest Lego game that I have played, by a long way. I really enjoyed that. The movie humour is present and very enjoyable but does not become tedious. There has been a lot of improvement in gameplay mechanics: the camera was great, the level length was just right, the free play areas were enjoyable and there were no frustrating 'jump just right' challenges. The graphics are a whole level above the graphics of other games because of the way they incorporated Lego scenery, and it's fantastic. The building minigame was too fast for me but was infrequent (unlike Lego Hobbit) and there were fewer collectibles of all sorts. Each level had 5 gold instruction manuals and one pair of pants (Honey, where are my pants?!). Gold bricks are not collected but represent your overall completion (there were 70, while Lego Marvel had 250). The variety of collectible characters is spot-on, there are relatively few, but they are all fun to play and can be unlocked easily (once you complete the appropriate level). The music within levels and in free play areas was never odious. Doing each level was fun - Lego games are often criticised for having no challenge to them, i.e., break stuff until you complete the level - but this game has the most variety (and least repetition) yet.In short, this is a really fun game to play. There is a lot of variety and humour; the game is colourful, the graphics are great and the levels are balanced. It's a lot shorter than other Lego games, and I have thus been able to completely finish it while still enjoying it.I'd say it's 'as good' as Lego Marvel, but there is a lot less of it. This game was released around the same time as Lego Hobbit, and this game is far better. I hope they continue with this style rather than Hobbit.Overall, I'd give this game a ... maybe 9 out of 10? [I'm having trouble figuring out why I shouldn't give it 10, though...]

												I love LEGO games. I loved LEGO the Movie. I feel, however, that this videogame is possibly the weakest entry in the series. It seems that it has been delegated to a "B" team - TT Fusion and it shows. Gone are delightful interactions, varied builds and awesome cutscenes. Instead - you get parts of the movie (with Star Wars characters blurred out) and repetitive gameplay.In most LEGO games you are required to mix a variety of "skills" and solve puzzles. In here, the element has been vastly simplified in favor of multiple "setpieces" where master builders build amazing huge things from 3 random elements on the screen. It is boring and happens over and over.Similarly, many characters always build the same thing (unikity builds the same ugly springboard 90% of the time she jumps into action).The game is also rather difficult to complete on free play mode as the way level triggers are set up tends to break if you have a character that allows you to bypass several story steps.If you are crazy for LEGO games and played all the others - give it a shot, but if you have other options - play those first. Personally I'd recommend LEGO Batman 3.

												I do enjoy this game, and highly recommend it to any fans of the LEGO video-game franchise. There's lots of similarities to some of the newest LEGO games as well as the older ones, such as high-jumping female characters, character selection wheels, and of course, buildable portions of levelsHowever, there are some major issues I have with the LEGO Movies' video-game partner:Firstly, the graphics. In reality, it makes it look plain awful for a company well-known for making their games look and feel like you're actually in the world that the game is set in. It looks like the older LSW (LEGO Star Wars) games. It looks incredibly childish and doesn't do the LEGO video-game franchise anything.Second, a pre-determined story that is incredibly predictable when you've seen the movie itself. I get that LEGO wanted to incorporate the movie into the game, but a different storyline would have given it more "oomph", as they say.Third, I found the levels to be rather long. There's a certain length that the first LEGO Batman: The Video-game had for it's levels, and the last chapter in each of the three campaigns was always the longest and most action-packed parts, Plus about every level had a boss fight, with the exception of a few where the would-be boss had already been captured and taken back to Arkham Asylum during the villains' side of the story.I'm not saying that it's all-around bad,'but there's a lot to be desired with it. I highly encourage you to play this game yourself and decide whether it's worth it or not.

Posted: October 3, 2014
												Compared to LEGO Marvel Super Heroes, this game feels like a gigantic step backwards. First off, this game feels like a poor movie to video game adaptation compared to the previous LEGO games like LEGO Indiana Jones or Lord of the Rings. I think the issue is that the game shackles itself to the movie and tries to follow it too closely, which breaks the whole theme of the movie which is about being creative with LEGOs. I think the game would have been much better off if it had been a prequel or parallel story of some sort that could better utilize the potential presented by the world of the LEGO movie.This unsatisfying story is exacerbated by the rather pitiful overworld that is miniscule in comparison to other recent LEGO games like Lord of the Rings or Marvel Super Heroes. Bricksburg is all of two city blocks, the wild west is the town square, and cloud cuckoo land is two or three (small) clouds. There's a few side quests to do in these hubs, but they pale in comparison to the previously mentioned LEGO games and make this game about half as long in comparison.To add insult to injury, the game has a surprisingly decent selection of vehicles that can be built from the treasures found in the missions but they can only be used in the bonus room (i.e. a kid's bedroom) which is basically sterile and devoid of interesting things to smash. A huge letdown from the bonus areas of the previous LEGO games.This is all on top of the standard LEGO game bugs which required me to restart some of the missions partway through because a script wouldn't work and I would be stuck. The character creator is also fairly pitiful.The one highlight of this game is that it adds giant mechs that can be used in some of the missions. Those would have been fun if Bricksburg had been a proper city and if the game allowed vehicles to be spawn in the hubs.Overall I was disappointed by this LEGO game and wouldn't recommend it unless you're trying to collect all the LEGO games. Even if you liked the LEGO movie, I would say go play some of the older LEGO action games or find an old LEGO creator game instead.

												While it is fun, I must say this game was pretty badly made. There's always some kind of issue whether it's with insane pop-in or with AI which is completely useless to say the least. For example, in Free Play after one of the game's end missions you have to escape a construction site but half the objects don't generate for several minutes making it barely playable. Your AI friendos don't even make an attempt to attack the enemy and instead just stand around and die. Meanwhile the enemy AI either swarms you and does nothing or swarms your team AI and dies.In terms of optimization this thing was terrible too. It took a while before this thing was even playable - It was locked at 1280x768 for crying out loud and you couldn't change it. And that isn't the only issue with the game's graphics, you have to make some major tweaks to make sure this game doesn't look blurry and fuzzy. Oh, and you can't access video options without actually starting the game. Character balancing is all over the place. Unikitty would be the only worthwhile character to play as if it weren't for the fact that the feline can't activate switches or climb certain "girl sections" such as jump walls and climbing walls. Metalbeard is extremely overpowered too. You really don't need to use anyone else after you find him because he kills everything, but if you want to move faster then your other option is Bad Cop who is nearly game-breaking. His laser straight-up instakills everything it touches making him extremely deadly. The gameplay is weird too, every now and then you get these puzzle sections which are just broken or badly thought out. For example, the enemy AI on the hacking game is TERRIBLE. They never accurately predict where to move and end up moving from one end of the map to the other. There is a "brick matching" minigame which requires ninja-esque reaction time to complete without losing studs and even then you will probably still lose some due to how unresponsive the game is. Lastly, there's the useless dancing sections. They are BROKEN. Broken, broken, broken. The opening one set in a construction site is barely responsive and the second, and last one is completely broken - You can't do anything but lose the game. They still haven't fixed that after quite a long time either.Lastly, this is a HUGE spoiler for The Lego Movie. It literally uses entire major scenes from The Lego Movie instead of real cutscenes and they're presented in a crappy aspect ratio which makes them barely watchable and therefore useless.Play it with your kids, they'll like it. It's long enough for them to be able to enjoy it but it's easy, has bad balancing, terrible optimization and bad puzzle design to match.

Posted: July 30, 2014
												The Lego Movie Game is, sadly, one of the worst Lego games to have come out for a while, on par with some of the first to be released. This game is first and foremost a movie tie-in, make no mistake. There is no original story, movie clips are used instead of in-game cutscenes, and don't expect any inivation beyond two bland mini-games.I've loved all the Lego games so far, and I got this one with the express purpose to play as Unikitty, and on that it delivered. What it didn't deliver is that scope that we've come to expect from modern Lego games, such as sprawling open worlds, a large cast of characters, and a host of special skills that are drip-fed to you throughout. Let's look at these in more detail:The character select screen may seem healthy, boasting 90-odd characters, but take a moment to consider who these characters are. Most are generic citizens who got mere seconds of screen time, or the mini-figured you find in the blind bags: Panda Man, Taco Tuesday Guy, and Larry the Barista are among the memorable characters you can play as, who only differ in apperance and the object they throw. The main character Emmet has not one, not three, but thirteen variations, all seperate (unlike most Lego games that stack variations of the same character on one spot) and all exactly the same, with two exceptions. Also, only the main characters have facial animations, and not even they get lip-synching when they talk.The world is divided into four areas and a bonus zone; Bricksburg, The Old West, Cloud Coocooland and the Octan Tower. These areas consist of more or less two rooms, with missions scattered around, with no central 'hub' to begin them. Characters are bought from the character select screen, as with the newer games, but the mini-figures can also be found scattered around to buy in-person, which is completely redundant. Within 10-hours of gameplay, taking my time, I have already finished the game, bought all the characters, and bought all the red blocks, making this the shortest Lego game I've ever played (and I've played most).The unique skills in this game are nothing mind-blowing: silver needs explosives, gold needs a laser, only construction-workers can repair, only women can be acrobatic (that's right, Batman cannot climb walls or jump around), only Master Builders can make objects, only Unikitty can use rainbow blocks, etc. etc. All very standard and mostly things we've seen before, too. Aside from Lord Buisness, who you get at the end of the game, most bonus obstacles can be cleared by the half-way point, let's say 6-hours in. It's a Lego game, so obviously you'll be going back and playing it all a second time in Free Play mode to unlock everything, but this certainly won't take anywhere near as long as the comparative colossus, Lego Batman 2.~In summation: This is a game for people who loved the movie. You'll get to see it all again and play with characters you probably won't otherwise get to, such as Unikitty. The gameplay is exactly as you'd expect, nothing breaks the formula, and anything new is few and far between. And you'd best hope you like the soundtrack, because you'll be hearing three particular songs an awful lot. In short: It's silly, short fun, but don't expect much more for you money beyond a playable advertisment. I recommend it because it is exactly what it is: It's not great, but it's not bad either, but it most certainly IS a movie tie-in game, and should be treated as such.

												The LEGO games follow a strict formula: Take a franchise/movie, recreate it in the most amazingly silly way possible, and make the audience replay memorable scenes in beautifully designed set-pieces. Star Wars, Middle Earth, Batman, you name it- in each LEGO game you get what could best be described as an affectionate parody, with MiniFigs and an awful lot of brick.-smashing. And The LEGO Movie Videogame is just the same, with all the good and the bad this brings.The LMV follows the basic plot of the movie: Normal everyday construction worker Emmet is pulled into an ancient prophecy that claims him to be the only one to save the world from a doomsday weapon called "The Kragle". Despite being utterly unqualified for the job he does his best, and hilarity ensues.If you know the movie (and you should) you'll find it hard not to smile a few minutes into the game. The complete cast is there, the setpieces are amazing and occasionally outshine the movie, the voice acting is pitch perfect and the undiluted charme of giant scenery build out of LEGO is as ever-present as ever. The game looks amazing and pulls a lot of awesome scenes together to form a narrative that is pretty close to the movie.As per usual, you control a growing cast of characters, each with their own ability set. Emmet can build sturdy objects with the proper instructions, and can smash through special bricks with his drill. Wyldstyle has some extra agility and can jump and climb on certain ledges, Batman gets his ever-useful Batarangs and grappling ropes, and so on. Using and combining these abilities make the bulk of the level's challenge, and the game does a good job of adding layers to the formula as the cast expands.Controls, also as usual, are nice and tight enough. The keyboard is a bit inferior to a good gamepad, but both work in a pinch. Switching characters and pulling off their moves is easily learned, and the game goes the extra mile to pop up tooltips if you keep missing a hint. Despite the cheerful toy aesthetic children will probably be overwhelmed by the action. There is always somethign going on, there is always something to do, and while death is cheap (you only lose a couple of studs, which are the in-game currency for everything) there is a certain difficulty here, a tad bit too easy for older, experienced players and a tad bit too hard for someone who's just learning the ropes.With a ton of unlockable characters, mission and freeplay game modes, and downright over-the-top-awesomeness, the LMV should be easy to recommend: It is an awesome game and filled to the brim with charme and action.Still, I need to stress that this game makes not exactly much sense if you do not know the movie. And even IF you know the movie, you'll have a hard time following events, so much that the levels stop being a string of related missions and instead become little self-contained bits connected with (occasionally edited) movie footage. And this is odd, because the game clearly knows what it is doing. The movie has a bike chase, which is awesome. The game stretches this chase over a whole level, and adds to it, and makes it just twice as awesome because this time, it's you playing that scene. I would have loved to see the team make their own plot, with in-game rendered cutscenes, and maybe explore the LEGO world a bit more.Still, this is nitpicking. The fun is there, and chasing down all achievements and unlockables will take a while- and this is a game where you abseil into a LEGO chicken, get encased in a rainbow eggshell, have a unicorn-cat smash that eggshell and build a toy-mouse car out of the bricks, which you can then ride, as Batman, all the while grumbling how rainbows are soo corny.Need I say more?

												Another brick in LEGO’s wall of games. In my opinion, The LEGO Movie Videogame is just another LEGO game; and thus has all the fun things you’d come to expect from one. Everything is good, well written and fun. The story is basically the same as the movie with a few minor changes to fit the game format. The gameplay is what you would expect, fun co-op, puzzle solving and of course, smashing everything in sight. The game has a semi-open world, that is very diverse, ranging from literal sunshines and rainbows to the desert heat of the wild west. The most defining feature of this game is the visual style, borrowed from the movie. Most LEGO games tend to have a mix of brick built objects and non-brick objects. However, this one stands out; due to being visually represented entirely by LEGO elements (save for the bonus level). Even the character animations are decisively LEGO, differing greatly from how characters move in other LEGO games. Unfortunately, aside from its distinct style, The LEGO Movie Videogame is just another LEGO game. It doesn’t change much from the formula and as such feels like an almost copy and paste from other previous games. There’s nothing wrong with the game, it’s just… average. There’s just not enough to make it stand out in the crowd of LEGO games. It’s not bad or below standard, just… average.  All in all, if you like LEGO games then, let’s face it, you’ve probably already bought this game. If you don’t mind the occasional LEGO game then there are better LEGO games to play. That’s not to say i don’t recommend getting this game, it still has its merit and is just as good as any LEGO game before it. So if you see it on sale, just give it a go; you won't be disappointed.

Another issue is that there are a lot of shooting enemies and avoiding them is a ♥♥♥♥♥ because your ground speed is just not fast enough. There are points where crowds need to talk and you’ll hear 4 voices. Plus, the voice actors sound like they’re doing it for a paycheck. It’s just terrible. Getting %100 in this game was probably the worst experience I've ever had with a LEGO game. Just the mixture of the music, the cutesyness, and the overall fact that this particular LEGO game oozes the fact it's made specifically for little kids made me hate every second that I was playing for the %100.So in summary, if you have kids this game will be great for them.If you're a grown adult, unless you really want the %100, buy one of the other LEGO games and save yourself some sanity.
